direction.raw_text: One of the most typical scenes of the day: a mass picket line outside a textile or shoe factory. And the picketing is anything but peaceful; the demonstrators are in direct conflict with the police, who are trying to keep an entrance open for strike-breakers. Whatever the general action, a small segment of struggle breaks off from it, and it is this that our CAMERA picks up: some police chasing some pickets or some pickets chasing some strike-breakers, the one faction pursuing the other up an alley with violent intent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A couple of the pursuers catch up to the pursued and assault them with clubs or other weapons. The fighting is bitter, dirty and noisy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The eight men gathered here in a game of five-card stud are clearly removed from the struggle outside, even though the SOUNDS of it are very close, coming through window opening on the alley. In fact the noise is so loud that the DEALER of the hand in progress reacts in annoyance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The player nearest the window shuts it. The Dealer, who also owns the restaurant, is the talkative type of poker player. Except for THE CINCINNATI KID, the other men at the table look like hoods of one sort or another: gunmen, labor spies, extortionists, what have you. The man who fancies himself the toughest of them all is named DANNY, and he and The Kid have almost all the money on the table between them, about a hundred dollars in front of each. No other player has more than a few dollars left, and now, as fifth cards are dealt, there is about forty dollars in the pot. Only four men are left in the hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns over his cards, leaving it up to The Kid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He counts out the money, which is almost all he has.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Attending to first things first, The Kid has been pulling in the pot, adding it to his own stake, and pocketing the total. Now as Danny accuses him again, The Kid looks him squarely in the face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stands up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks off, disappearing through a door marked "MEN."
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: KITCHEN IN SLEAZY RESTAURANT NEAR RAILROAD

dialogue.raw_text: Somebody shut the goddam window. Let a man think.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Possible straight gets a -- (deals the card)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: lovely little four.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On the last hand even, you couldn't give me a break.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I put the brakes on your straight, didn't I? (he laughs; no one else does; he deals to The Kid) There you are, son, a gorgeous deuce.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (deals to Danny) And our lucky friend from Chicago gets a queen with his pair of sixes. Little lady make you happy, Buster?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Deal to yourself, clown.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dealer gives himself a -- (deals card and groans) I might have known. (to Danny) Bet your sixes, Buster.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I told you not to call me that. (then as the dealer turns away) Cost you -- (counts out his money) Ninety-four bucks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Biggest pot of the whole game, I got to drop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to First Player) Interested?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wouldn't call you if I had a pair higher'n sixes. Which I ain't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't seem like he'd bet out without something better than the sixes, does it? (fingers hole card as if to fold) Cost me every cent I've won since yesterday afternoon. (studies Danny's face) But I tell you, I got this stubborn streak. Call the ninety-four dollars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indignantly) You can't have better than a pair of kings!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I'm not claiming anything that fine. (turns over an eight, making a pair of them) Just enough to beat the pair of sixes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You seen my hole card, you bastard! (indicating Dealer) He was dealing them high.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You stole that dough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You better watch those loose lips of yours, you want to have any teeth left behind them -- Buster.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You wouldn't of shelled out ninety- four bucks -- KID I called you on account of I didn't think you had another pair or another six and I know a punk like you would get greedy and try and buy the last hand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He is waiting when the door opens abruptly, and Danny appears, his right hand in his coat pocket. The Kid's hand goes to his own pocket and as he whirls around, a straight razor appears in it, its blade snapped open. Pushing Danny to the wall with one hand, he keeps him pinned there with the razor in the other, while he bolts the door. Danny gets his right hand out of the pocket with a gun in it, but The Kid moves the razor blade against his neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the gun clatters to the floor, and the others force the door, The Kid takes a step backward to provide enough momentum, then swings at Danny's middle with his left, dropping him, then jumps up on the wash basin and wriggles his way out through a window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Drop it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : MAIN TITLES Danny recovers his balance and his gun, unbolts the door just before it is smashed in, and runs with the others to get out of the building and after The Kid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The conflicting parties from the picket lines have moved on. The Kid drops from the window to the ground and starts to run toward the railroad yards. A few moments later, Danny and four other poker players appear and run after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The chase across the tracks goes on behind the Credits. The Kid's pursuers split into two groups to cut him off, and they seem to have succeeded in cornering him against a track on which a passenger train is bearing down, headed for the station. His dubious chance of escape depends on his getting beyond this track in front of the train, which, with a burst of speed, he manages to accomplish just in time. The passenger train divides The Kid from his pursuers, and we PAN with the train into the depot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LOUIS The train slowly stops. Amid all the atmosphere of arrival in a day when the Pullman car was still the ultimate in travel, LANCEY HODGES appears on a platform, takes his bag from the Pullman porter and passes it on to a Red Cap before he has descended the steps. He walks with other passengers and Red Caps toward the center of the station.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shooting through the Meeting of the Rivers fountain across Market Street to the Romanesque building with its campanile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lancey getting into a taxi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TAXI - PROCESS - DAY Lancey sits in serene repose in back, watching the sights go by. The HACKIE steals a couple of looks at him in the rear vision mirror.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What you looking for, mister?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do I have to be looking for something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can pretty much tell.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can pretty much tell what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some guys come to town, I can tell if they're looking for something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you think I'm looking for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you're looking for girls, I can fix you up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I strongly doubt if you could fix me up. In that department.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well what are you looking for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're looking for a clout in the head if you don't keep your face to the road.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A doorman takes Lancey's suitcase as Lancey pays the Hackie and walks into the hotel. A SECOND HACKIE whose cab is at the curb reacts to seeing Lancey and steps forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But the second hackie has followed Lancey into the hotel.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, you know who that is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lancey crosses to the desk to register as the Second Hackie goes to a row of phone booths and enters one. He dials with his eyes on Lancey registering.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone) Shorty? Want to hear who just checked into the Park Sherman... Yes, you do. Lancey Hodges.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He is talking on the phone while he hands out score sheets and shoes to some bowlers. He is just as excited by the report as the Hackie is.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The Kid know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He is talking on the telephone behind the bar.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Somebody sure as hell ought to tell The Kid. (hangs up) Lancey Hodges is in town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He reacts to the news in a big way. CAMERA PANS to another DRINKING MAN, who is equally impressed. They exchange looks.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Kid's been laying for him a long time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: You ask me, The Kid'll go after him as soon as he hears.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Who's got a better right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We are in the front room where the pool tables are. Through an open door in b.g., we can see the unadvertised but unconcealed other activity of the establishment: a poker game in progress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid enters the place through the front door, still a little dishevelled from his escape.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You going to tell The Kid, Shooter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hell, I can't not tell him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's where he's been headed for years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in greeting) Hey!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What you say, Kid?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Hoban.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where you been? Boys been holding a chair for you in back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Business opportunity come along. Something too good to pass up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Turn a profit?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, did okay. Except I almost had it took back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, one of those.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (concerned) You been in too many rough ones lately, Kid. You can't go on forever, coming out in one piece.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got to build my stake, Aren't enough chances in this town to let one go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're too good, that's your trouble. People who know you're the Cincinnati Kid, they don't want to sit down with you -- KID For nickels and dimes... Thing is I've about used up St. Louis.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nodding) The streets are getting full of guys you've hustled.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Been thinking about Miami. There's nothing to keep me here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a moment) The hell there isn't (as the Kid looks at him) Lancey Hodges' in town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah? (then) The Man himself, here in St. Louis -- I might just stick around Shooter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lancey is on the phone, sitting on the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hangs up and some of the strength seems to go out of him, as if he had been through too long a sustained effort. His eyes show that he is feeling pain and he breathes deeply.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone) Mr. Schlaegel? How are you? And your enchanting wife?... Tomorrow is quite convenient... I generally prefer stud but you name it... Your stakes are my pleasure, sir... Thank you, why don't we make it after lunch? My diet these days is enough to spoil anyone else's appetite... A pleasure, sir. Please remember me to your charming wife.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Harold Street leads to the river and we follow The Kid and The Shooter as they walk down it in the gathering dusk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They walk along, The Shooter pursing his lips thoughtfully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid nods as they come to where an old wooden pier extends into the river. Along the river bank can be seen a small portion of the mile-long Hooverville that stretches up and down the Mississippi.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (lighting a cigar) I been seeing it coming for a long time, Kid. Long time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I ain't exactly been hiding it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, you ain't been hiding it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well I got to know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, you got to know. We all got to know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sometime or other we got to find out how much juice we got.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's why I had to tell you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ever sit down with him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I have.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, what happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing. Nothing at all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You lost.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't lose. I'm too good to lose when I set my mind to it. I play poker a certain way, Kid. I've had my Lancey Hodges. Only with me it was Whistling Sam Magee to New Orleans.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (respectfully) I heard about him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well then you know it all... about 20 years ago it was, maybe more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why, I lost it. It dried me up on the inside for a long, a very long time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I been where I'm going, know what I mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: They walk out on the pier and eventually stop, look out at the river, watching the working boats. They have their thoughts; The Shooter smoking his cigar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They start back off the pier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ahead, on the levee, CHRISTIAN is seen waiting for The Kid. She has not yet seen them as they approach off the pier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Christian sees them and moves toward them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shooter turns away abruptly as Christian arrives, giving her a brief nod.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid takes Christian's arm automatically; he watches The Shooter walk way down Harold Street. He and Christian head in another direction. She is humming a mountain tune.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is surprised by this and, in her own hesitant way, curious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at her fondly and, for one fleeting moment of weakness, is actually tempted to tell her about Lancey. But it is too sharp a break with tradition.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You think I'm ready?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after some time, several seconds of thoughtful puffing) Kid, I don't think you're ready.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quickly) Oh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you're not going to take my word for it, are you? Are you now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I ain't. I can't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know, I know. You got to find out for yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't figure to take him right away. But if I can hang in there long enough, I can outlast him. If I can outlast him, I got a chance. You admit that, don't you, that I got a chance?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I already said I didn't think you were ready.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you think you were ready when you sat down with Whistling Sam Magee?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Kid, I thought I was the best stud poker player in the world. I'm telling you now, I thought I was the best.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I don't think I'm just a cocky square with a fair hand with cards. I got something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, you ain't no cocky square. And you probably got something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay. And I ain't saying that you was either when you sat down with Whistling Sam Magee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you got the stuff, being a little cocky don't hurt you none.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, would you say if I got any chance at all?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This much of a chance. If Lancey is not right. If he's got a cold, or his stomach ulcer is acting up, or something like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But then everybody'd see he wasn't right and it wouldn't prove nothing. Listen, we got to have it understood. If he's not right, we call it off till he is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're set on a real showdown, aren't you? Your mind's all made up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got to. You said yourself I got to. I'm overdue.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, you been around a long time -- I was a lot younger than you when I went up against Whistling Sam -- But you'd be kinda young too, to be The Man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I gotta find out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a pause) Want me to set it up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gratefully) I wish you would, Shooter Man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, what if he turns me down?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He won't, the way I'll spread the word. He'll have to take you on, someone in your class. If he ducked it, that'd make you The Man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think he knows I'm around?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He can smell meat like you a mile and a half up the river. He knows you're around and he'll sit down with you. You want to butt heads with The Man, I'll set it up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's your woman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wouldn't want to wait around too long. I want to get in and get it over with.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He must of come to St. Louis for a big money game. I'll probably get asked do I want to deal it for them. And however long that takes, he'll have to rest up for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, well, if he's tooling a dollar, I can understand that. Sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got much of a stake?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Close to three grand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Work on it. But three grand will give you a ride and even if you don't win, why you'll come away with a good idea of what you're made of. But once you go in Kid you can't quit. You get that straight right now. Two of you go in and only one of you can come out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, school's out. I damn sure don't want no lessons. I want everything he's got.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's the only way to be, Kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When we leaving town, Kid? This week?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I won't be ready. Not for a while.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought -- KID Might even turn out we don't go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You must feel different about it than you did Saturday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I'm feeling a little different. (TIME LAPSE)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It is night and the room is lit only by a single lamp where Christian sits in her nightgown on a chair by the window, turning over the pages of a mail-order catalogue. In f.g. The Kid lies on his back under a sheet on the bed, his eyes closed and his hands clasped tensely behind his neck. He opens his eyes and turns to look at her. The movement catches her eye, and she instantly stops turning the pages, afraid the noise has disturbed him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She waits at the foot of the bed for him to come slowly to a decision.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She goes into the bathroom, where she turns the water on gently so the tub will take a long while to fill. Then she takes a bottle of alcohol from the medicine chest and returns to the bedroom with it. She stands in front of him waiting for him to move, but The Kid is singularly listless. Not till she sets the bottle down does he respond by turning his face to the pillow. She goes right to work on his shoulder muscles, and she seems to know what she is doing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She slaps him on the rump and straightens up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He doesn't move but just stays relaxed and closes his eyes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's all right. You don't have to act like a cat. You're not bothering me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want me to turn out the light?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. I'm overtired, that's why I can't sleep. (sits up and swings his feet to the floor) Why can't you sleep?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (lightly) Undertired, I guess. If a person rests all day, she doesn't have much to rest up from at night. (stands up) Why don't you have a nice hot bath? I could give you a rubdown and then you could have a nice hot bath, and then maybe you could sleep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Kay. Can't hurt to try it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did you do with yourself this time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Last night I went to a movie with The Shooter's woman. French movie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In French?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They had the words in English at the bottom of the picture. But The Shooter's woman knew what they were saying without it. Pig's woman or somebody told me she went to college.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure. Majored in man-eating.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think maybe she really did go. But I never quite dared to up and ask her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't know you ran with The Shooter's woman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We got to be kind of friendly when you both were in that three-day game down to Cairo. 'Course she's older'n me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And been around more. A lot more. What was the movie like?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Weird. It wasn't a straight story where you knew whose side you were on, the way you do in regular pictures.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: American pictures.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. There were lots of things I didn't understand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What was it about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, there's this town in Europe a long time ago where they get a message from a Spanish general he's coming to spend the night with his troops. So all the men are scared silly about what the soldiers will do to them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing weird about that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But all the wives and daughters tell the men to go hide somewhere and let them bargain with the enemy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That don't make much sense.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait. The way they handle it is they go to bed with the Spaniards. And the next morning the soldiers go off peacefully and everybody's happy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Including the husbands and fathers? Don't they suspect?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's part of what I wasn't sure of. I guess they know what went on but they care more about their safety and their money than they do about their honor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then they got their heads screwed on straight. Honor's just an idea. You can't see or feel it and you can't eat it and you sure as hell can't get any mileage on it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll just turn off the bath water.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Christian, humming softly, turns off the water, takes a large towel from a rack and puts it on a stool by the tub where it will be more convenient for him. She lingers to test the water with her finger and do anything else she can think of to assure maximum comfort for her man. Then she steps back into the bedroom. The sight of him makes her advance cautiously and confirm her suspicion that he is asleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Shooter's woman, is sitting up in bed working on her eyebrows and listening to MUSIC turned up LOUD on a radio. The bedside phone RINGS, barely audible above the radio. She answers it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gets no answer, which is no wonder in view of the noise from the radio. But the radio is across the room and it's slightly easier for her to get out of the side of the bed she's on, and go to the door of The Shooter's room. She opens this and we see The Shooter in bed in his own small quarters, reading a magazine. He turns around inquiringly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Shooter picks up the phone but before he speaks into it, he pantomimes to her that he won't be able to hear over the radio. She seems to regard the request as an imposition but she does go grudgingly to the radio and turns it down a little before she returns to her bed and her cosmetic chore.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone) Hello... Yes, it is. You want him? (calling) Shooter! Telephone! Shooter!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Phone for you. I always seem to be the one to answer it, no matter who it's for.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (getting up) If you'd rather we put it in my room -- MELBA Are you kidding?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone) Hello?... Well, hello. What brings you to our fair city? Little action, maybe?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lancey, dressed for bed, is on the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: INT. SHOOTER'S APARTMENT SHOOTER (into phone) Owns most of the Schlaegel Brewery. Braumeister beer. The Shooter sits down on the edge of Melba's bed, the movement jostling her so she pricks herself with her tweezers. She exclaims in protest and gives him a dirty look that makes The Shooter stand right up again.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone) How could you guess, Shooter? I was invited by a Mr. William Schlaegel --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (into phone) As he put it, rather bluntly, I felt, we don't want everyone to have to watch everyone else dealing to see to it they don't make any little accidental errors by mistake. I told him a man couldn't ask for a better guarantee of a fair-and-square game than having The Shooter deal it. So if you're willing, we're meeting at two o'clock in the afternoon. Ask for Mr. Schlaegel's suite at the Park Sherman... Good. I'm glad you can do it, Shooter. Be a pleasure to see you again... (then) Oh pretty much the same... Just have to be a little careful about smoking and drinking and eating -- and breathing. See you tomorrow. Good night. He hangs up the phone, settles himself in a comfortable chair, and opens a heavy book. CAMERA MOVES in CLOSE enough to reveal the title: Prescott's CONQUEST OF PERU.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is midday outside but the window shades are tightly drawn to keep the daylight from disturbing The Kid, who is still asleep. Christian, dressed for the street, moves from the bedroom to the kitchen-living room which is the remainder of the two-room apartment. Finding paper and pencil, she writes a quick note and leaves it on the kitchen table, then starts out. (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: featuring one bathing suit displayed among others in an end- of-season sale with some such advertising message as "All bathing suits reduced 1/3 for clearance!" The particular suit is a two-piece one, exposing two or three inches of bare midriff -- the first modest forerunner of the trend that led eventually to the bikini.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Would you wear it in public?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: to include Christian and Melba looking at the display.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They start walking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Wouldn't be much point wearing it in private. Sure, why not, as long as you don't have a bulge to hide?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know, Melba.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking her over) My guess is there isn't anything about you needs hiding. But I'll give you a more definitive opinion at the bath.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (startled) At the what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Turkish Bath. After we're through shopping. I'm treating you, Christian.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I never been. I'm not even sure what you do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't do anything. That's what's so marvelous. They do it to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: finds Christian and Melba among the perspiring females.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The third time I stayed. Never went back to the boarding house except to pick up my things.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And that side of it's held up? No complaints in the bed department?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, just one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (intrigued) Yes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The nights he isn't there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He really does that to you, does he? You got one of the rare ones.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Christian and Melba are on adjoining rubbing tables, a curtain separating them from the waist down only. Their heads are close enough so they can talk without their masseurs necessarily hearing every word they say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is at a loss for a word.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Christian looks blank.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You find a guy, you love him, and that's it. It's supposed to just go on like that for life. Right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: According to the propaganda, right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But it isn't my life, it's his life, with me tacked on. You have any idea what it's like to be a hash slinger in a cheap restaurant?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, honey, the stock crash wafted me right from the daisy chain into unmarried bliss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's hell, if you'll excuse the word. But I didn't want to quit. The Kid made me. I felt I ought to hang on to something that was me away from him. You know what I mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure. Some girls solve the problem by taking on an extra guy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm serious. Having children might take care of it, I don't know. Or -- this is really a terrible thing to admit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your most sordid secrets are safe with me. Confess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If he was rich, or famous -- MELBA Why don't you give him both?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) Why not? Well, if he was rich and famous, maybe I wouldn't mind so much just being -- just a woman to him. Do you think that might make it seem more worthwhile somehow?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Somehow! Are you sincere, sweetie? (reacting to the masseur's touch) Oooo -- divine. (to Christian) Isn't this heaven?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not sure. In a way it seems soft of --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Decadent? Depraved?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wicked?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what I meant by heaven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lancey, Shooter and five other men are sitting in comfortably padded chairs around a well-appointed poker table. Everything about the game is in sharp contrast to the one The Kid played in. It is played with chips - expensive ones; there are a couple of bottles of wine on ice, fine cigars, a tray of sandwiches, etc. Lancey's opponents are all wealthy types; two of them could be Texas oil men. The youngest, a good- looking man of thirty, is BILL SCHLAEGEL. The Shooter, as nonplaying dealer, distributes fifth cards to the four remaining players in the hand, and both Lancey and Bill end up with four cards of one suit showing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bill silently tosses in two of the rarest and highest ranking chips on the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A phone RINGS and the Third Wealthy Type answers it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Third Wealthy Type takes the phone and speaks on it during the ensuing. The Second Wealthy Type crosses to the bar and fixes himself a drink. Lancey takes in his winnings. Bill hasn't recovered from the blow. There is a hiatus in the game.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (as he deals) Still queens -- possible flush -- no help -- possible flush.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Queens check to the possibles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Check.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Check.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fold.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And up two.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fold.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Biggest pot yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Call the two thou.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning over queen of his suit) Queen high.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indignantly) Jack high. Can you beat that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He just did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Second Wealthy Type) It's your office.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dallas or Tulsa?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She just said office.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How the bloody hell did you figure out I didn't have the king or the ace?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I recollect a young fellow putting the same question to Eddie the Dude. It was a game in the grand lounge of the "J.M. White, Third," the largest paddle-wheeler ever built. "Son," Eddie told him, "All you paid was the looking price. Lessons are extra." (turns to Shooter) First time I heard of this Cincinnati Kid was in New Orleans, at Yeller's. I knew right away I'd have to play him someday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll enjoy his game.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I may admire it. But if he's all that good, I doubt if I'll enjoy it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The tougher the competition, the better you used to like it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've learned to take everything in moderation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It is early evening. The Kid approaches the restaurant with Christian on one arm, Melba on the other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles at them both and goes off. They move to enter the restaurant. (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Melba) Have a drink with us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Better not. Shooter said they'd break at seven, and he has to have his food first, then his nap. (looking The Kid over) You know, there's a day in your life I'm looking forward to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In my life?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The day The Kid becomes The Man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The plates with the remains of their main course are in front of them. The Kid pours what's left of a bottle of beer into his glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She lowers her eyes, finding it hard to say the words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks o.s. raising a hand to summon the check. (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How'd you sleep Kid?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I slept okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hope you don't mind my not being there when you woke up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No I don't mind -- (then) What she was talking about, Shooter's woman -- I'm going up against a big game soon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She told me. It's a very big game, I hear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will it be long?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why? (then) What's the matter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought -- KID Thought what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd go home and see Mama.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wouldn't be able to spare you much change.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I wouldn't want much. Bus is really the best way to go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would a hundred fish do it? For the bus and something nice to bring your Mama?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That would be fine, Kid. Just fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When would you want to go?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's no reason for not going right now unless --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Unless what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Unless you wanted to go to bed first.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you want to? Would you like it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Un-huh. I'd like it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want dessert?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. You?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shakes head) Coffee?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't need it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Neither do I.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It is dark in the room and dark outside, the street lamps furnishing only enough light for a faint border around the window shade. Christian's head and nude back move into the Shot; she pulls the shade aside to look out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - CHRISTIAN'S P.O.V. - NIGHT The time is a few minutes before ten.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She lets the shade fall back into place. Moving quietly in the darkness, she begins to dress. CAMERA PULLS BACK and PANS to include The Kid, lying on the bed with a sheet over him. He seems to be asleep until he speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Christian abandons the process of dressing herself and sits down in the easy chair to answer this question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She doesn't comment one way or the other, nor does he press the point.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gets up and begins to pack her clothes in an old suitcase. After a moment The Kid gets out of bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She closes the suitcase and puts on the one dress she hasn't packed. The Kid, dressed now, watches her for a moment then goes to the bottom drawer of the dresser and opens it to reveal a stack of money under a shirt. He takes five clean twenty-dollar bills and counts them on to the top of the dresser, snapping the crisp leaves gambler style. Then he stoops down again and takes out two more twenties, adding them to the pile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He doesn't actually hand her the money. He leaves it on top of the dresser and she goes over and takes it, folding the bills and putting them in her change purse. The Kid picks up her suitcase, and she leads the way into the other room. At the front door she stops and looks back at the little apartment for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at him for a moment, then exits. He follows. (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You still haven't said it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Said what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you're coming back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe I ought to stay with Mama and Papa a while, and see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's to see?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I never did like city streets.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh-huh. The promise didn't fulfill itself for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Promise?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come to the city and all. Electric lights and flush toilets. All the pretty dreams -- it was all promise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know if you do or not Kid -- You're city -- and I'm country -- You grew up with it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think that's why you're going -- because you like it so much better in the country.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What will you do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I've got that big game.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I heard he's The Man for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. If I won, there would be a lot of money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll win. You been coming on strong a long way. This is your time. (then after a long moment) Come home with me to Mama's Kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (finally) I'm sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gently) I know you are honey -- I know it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll go down to the bus with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't have to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (starting to dress) I'll go down with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a pause) Kid -- KID Yeah?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is going to sound kind of funny to you, but I want to ask it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you think there's any chance, if you do win this big game, that you might do something else besides cards? (hastily) I don't mean never play poker. I just mean not have it be the only thing you do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hell, it's the only thing I know how to do. What else is there for a guy never finished school? College graduates are walking the streets looking for jobs -- trained people, engineers, scientists!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I realize -- KID (not letting her speak) When you're The Man, you don't have to hustle -- When you're The Man, The Best, the Big Money comes around on their knees just beggin' to hustle you. I'm not goin' to quit. I'm goin' to win.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I can see that. Of course I didn't say quit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well you see how it is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a moment) Christian, you aren't doing this to be off my back, in case I lose?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I been thinking about it a long time. I been planning to go home and see how I felt about things.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And this just helped you decide.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then don't go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (firmly) No, this is your time -- Now you go on Honey and you play The Man -- I'll be at Mama's.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wish it could be more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't guess I'll ever forget these rooms, Kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't guess I will either.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You going to move?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I win, it won't be good enough. If I lose, I lose it all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Kid and Christian sit in silence. She puts her hand on his. (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid and Christian sit on a bench in the waiting room, still silent. He has her suitcase between his legs and a pile of magazines on his lap. She looks at a clock and gets to her feet. He follows her to the door, carrying the suitcase and magazines.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Christian boards a bus that has seen better days. On the steps she turns to take the bag from him, but he follows her on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Christian takes a seat. The Kid puts her suitcase in the overhead rack and hands her the magazines, none of which would be classed as heavy reading.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They don't kiss. He turns and goes out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Goodbye, Kid. Good luck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodbye, Christian.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: There are not many passengers boarding this bus. After a couple of moments, the driver closes the door and starts off. Christian waves from the window, and The Kid waves back to her. When the bus has gone, he walks around the outside of the terminal to the front.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are a couple of cabs at a taxi stand. One of the hackies offers his services to The Kid, but The Kid declines. He wants to walk. (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is midday and the poker game is almost twenty- four hours old. Our attention is focused on Bill Schlaegel, who is writing out a check.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Shooter takes advantage of the lull in the proceedings to move to the telephone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lancey gives him a quick look, finding this a bit thick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bill puts his check down in front of The Shooter's place, and gets to his feet.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Four stacks? Right, Schooter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Four.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you for the entertainment, gentlemen. My particular gratitude to you, Lancey. It's been a rare pleasure to watch a great artist at work. Thank you for the privilege.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well now, son, you're quite welcome. Can't say I recall another man, in all my days on the three rivers, who seemed to find it quite so pleasurable losing all that money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good day, gentlemen. You're welcome to use the premises as long as you like.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: with Bill as he passes The Shooter, who is waiting on the phone while the hotel operator dials his number. Bill gives him a friendly pat on the back, and speaks in a low, harsh voice for The Shooter's ears alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bill goes out. Shooter looks after him as his party comes on the phone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I want to see you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone) Hi, Kid. Shooter here. Listen, I told the woman I'd take her to the ball park, but I'm still working. How about you and Christian take her out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (into phone) Christian's gone home to see her folks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (into phone) Oh. (then) Well listen, would you mind taking her yourself? The gang'll be there, in the section... Thanks. Appreciate it. See you. He hangs up, returns to the table and starts to shuffle the cards in his own spectacular way. (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LOUIS - DAY A game is in progress between the Cardinals and another National League club. The batter at the plate connects for a long one. CAMERA FOLLOWS the flight of the ball.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are making their way to meet their friends in the section they prefer. They stop to watch the ball as the fans around them rise to their feet. The section they have just reached is in the sun, overlooking the outfield.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An outfielder races back and makes a difficult catch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They start on their way again. CAMERA PANS ahead of them to a group consisting of Hoban; HOBAN'S WOMAN, still sexy in her forties; PIG, whose name could derive with equal justification from either his looks or his manners; and SOKAL, who talks colloquial American with a Central European accent. The group as a whole is notable because its members have not risen to their feet with everyone else, because all the men are basking in the sun with their shirts off, because they view the action on the field with detachment, and because, nevertheless, they are constantly placing bets on details of the game. Now, as people around them resume their seats, Sokal is able to confirm that the fly ball has been caught.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid and Melba join them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He and Melba sit down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: While he is talking, Melba unbuttons his shirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes his shirt off. Melba finds some suntan lotion in her bag, and applies it to her face and arms, her eyes rarely straying from The Kid.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Hoban) You owe me two fish on the out, plus three on the inning, minus two on no strikeouts so far.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hiya, Kid. Getting yourself in shape for The Man? (to Melba) Shooter still on the job?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where's Christian?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in a whisper) Lay off that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What'd she do, take off? So did mine. Don't lose no sweat, Kid, there's plenty more where they came from. All shapes and sizes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi, Hoban. Sokal. Pig.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Sokal) Boyer. One to two on the sacrifice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Five to three, I'll give you. Two- fifty against one-fifty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mark it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I figure they'll walk him. Fill up first.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not with who's coming up. I'll take the same odds.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get some of this sun.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to The Kid) Mark it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Melba) Guess I will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bunting, Sokal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The bunt is fielded by the first baseman, who throws to second for the out. There is no play at first.

direction.raw_text: Without waiting for his approval, she goes ahead and spreads the lotion on his skin, painstakingly, as if she were applying paint to canvas, working it in, one area at a time, with her fingertips.

direction.raw_text: The men concentrate their attention on the diamond. CAMERA MOVES IN to Melba's fingers playing across The Kid's midriff. From the field comes the sharp CRACK of a bat against a ball, followed by a SHOUT from the crowd. CAMERA PANS UP to the faces of Melba and The Kid as he looks at her and she meets his gaze with inviting eyes.

dialogue.raw_text: So they pitched to him. I still win.

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) Mais tu es charmant -- CUT TO:

direction.raw_text: With the same look of invitation in her eyes.

dialogue.raw_text: Charmant. Come here, please.

direction.raw_text: . Wearing the same clothes as at the ball park, she is sitting in a chair with her legs tucked under her. The Kid is sitting on a straight chair at a table on which he has a cup of coffee. They are alone in the apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stands up but doesn't move toward her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid stays where he is as she comes up against him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He kisses her and lets himself enjoy it for a while, then pulls away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Any special reason?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Me. I'm special.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure you are. You're The Shooter's woman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right. And maybe I'll go on being The Shooter's Woman, even after you and I have had our little romp. What do you think about that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: First place, Old Shooter'll come barging through that door any minute. He said they were winding it up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No barging. He doesn't have his key with him. (stands up) Have to buzz from downstairs. (moves toward him provocatively) So we can treat ourselves to a little sample of things to come.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Also it don't mean anything to you, you're Christian's friend?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Honey, she lost her franchise the minute she got on that bus. You know that. (her arms around him) I have a shaky sense of security, Kid. Don't make me feel unwanted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No good?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know damn well how good it was. Where's a pack of cards?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do we need cards for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gin or casino, you name it. All I know is we're switching to another indoor sport.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The poker game is over. Two of the Wealthy Types have already departed; one is finishing a drink on the way out; another is putting his winnings into his wallet; a third is writing out a check. Lancey and The Shooter still sit at the table in f.g.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Lady Fingers'll want to come, I bet, and she's right on the edge of her stake. She could spell me dealing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, sure. Haven't seen the dear old bitch in fifteen years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, that's it, then. Monday night, Room Three-Eleven at the Dorset Hotel. And may the best man win.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, that's how it usually comes out in the long run. You think this boy is going to give me trouble, Shooter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, he's going to give you trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want it to be one of those marathon games. Not any more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like the session with The Portugee at Jolly's in Omaha. Remember?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, sure. Longest game I ever played though, I was a kid on my way to the Klondike gold rush. At Soapy Smith's in Skagway. Four nights and three days.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You win?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Depends how you look at it. When we wound up, the Yukon River had frozen over and you couldn't get through to Dawson City till the following June. Made myself a Hundred and fifty bucks and missed the gold rush.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You been around a long time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That is undeniably true. But it doesn't mean I'm ready to retire. How old is this boy of yours?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Twenty-six, twenty-eight, something like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, now, makes me feel a whole lot better, knowing that. I was thirty- six when I sliced up Eddie the Dude. This Kid of yours is just going to have to wait a few years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He is standing by an elevator in f.g. keeping watch on a row of room doors including the site of the poker game. FELIX is an impressive physical specimen whose capacity for brutality is masked by a quiet, deferential manner. When he sees a door open, he moves so as to be out of The Shooter's sight as the latter comes toward him. It isn't until The Shooter rounds the corner in f.g. and presses the button for the elevator that Felix makes his presence known.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The doors of the elevator open. Felix yields precedence to The Shooter and they enter it. The doors close.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, Mr. Shooter, sir, but Mr. Schlaegel asked me to remind you how eager he was to see you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: An elevator opens, and The Shooter and Felix come out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I ought to call my woman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, of course. They always like to know it if you're going to be late for supper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: with them as The Shooter leads the way to a row of telephone booths and enters one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are sitting at the table in a game of casino. She plays an ace from her hand, adds a seven from the board, and lays them both on top of a three-card pile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He plays an eight and takes in the whole pile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The telephone RINGS. She stands up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Still building eights.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks for putting it together for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not my game.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Want to know what is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: her to the phone. She picks it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She reaches a hand around to the back of her neck, fiddles with her dress a moment, then beckons in The Kid's direction.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone) Hello -- Oh, hi, sugar -- why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He doesn't understand what she wants but he gets up and comes to her obligingly, CAMERA MOVING with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She points to the hook-and-eye fastener at the top of the zipper that runs down the back of her dress. The Kid pantomimes the question "What for?" but she just wiggles her finger impatiently at the fastener while speaking into the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid still doesn't know what she has in mind but it seems easier to humor her than not. He unfastens the hook. Melba smiles her thanks and, to his consternation, reaches back and pulls the zipper all the way down. She places her hand over the mouth-piece of the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She steps out of the dress.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone) What's the switch?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone) Whose idea was that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Kid) He's not coming home now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone) Whatever you say, Shooter man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (into phone) Explain to The Kid, will you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Melba in her bra and panties, snuggles against The Kid.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone) He'll understand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (into phone) Tell him they decided to play a little longer, and I'll call him at his place later when the game's over... Right. Goodbye, honey. He hangs up the phone and emerges from the booth. CAMERA MOVES with him as he joins Felix and they walk toward the hotel entrance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid, his policy toward this new situation still unresolved, holds her lightly while he tries to think it out aloud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She invites a kiss and he obliges her. But there is a contrary force at work inside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again she presses close to him and again he savors her for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts out. Melba stares after him, scarcely able to believe what is being done to her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, Melba -- MELBA I have to tell you first. You're sitting down with Lancey next Monday night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wish it was sooner. I wish it was tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shooter'll give you all the details later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't like waiting that long.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's not kick a gift horse in the teeth, sugar. We've got this time together. Let's try to "fill each unforgiving minute with sixty seconds worth of distance run."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, what I was going to say before, I don't want you to think I'm being some kind of jerk or I don't feel you'd be great to sack up with.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then let's cut the filibuster.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've made dolls that were friends of mine's wives. I figured if they were willing, they were doing it to their husbands, I wasn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course. Any other attitude, you're degrading the woman. You're not treating her as a person with a mind of her own, but as somebody's property.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Only thing is, it's different with The Shooter than anybody else. He's so straight, I got the obligation to be straighter with him than other people. So do you. On account of we both owe him plenty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought we just agreed that what you and I did was strictly between us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't be. (decisively, pulling away from her with a pat of dismissal) Shooter's the closest thing to family I got. It's almost like he was my old man. Don't you see how that's got a bearing on us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, it means I'm your mother.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: An expensive automobile, with Felix at the wheel and The Shooter next to him in the front seat, approaches the main house of a lavish estate in a St. Louis suburb. It continues along the driveway past the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In swimming trunks, Bill is spoon-feeding a year-old BABY in a highchair. Looking o.s., he waves in greeting to The Shooter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks from the parked car toward the pool, returning Bill's salutation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: from behind The Shooter as he approaches the attractive family group that includes, besides Bill and the baby, a FIVE-YEAR-OLD GIRL who is having her hair brushed after swimming by ROSANNA SCHLAEGEL, her beautiful mother. A family dog completes the picture. Bill continues to feed the baby as he hails The Shooter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As she goes off, Rosanna cautions June about her hair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As soon as his wife is gone, Bill goes right to the topic he doesn't want to discuss in her presence.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Shooter -- very generous of you to come on such short notice. Rosanna you know, and I think you've met my daughter June. (indicating baby) No point introducing you to William the Fourth. He has a bad memory for names.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (greeting them in turn) Mrs. Schlaegel. How are you, June. What's it all about, Bill?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Little something I'd like to sound you out on. But the least I can do is offer you a drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like me to fix it, love?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wonderful. Why don't you do a batch of your Bloody Marys? If that's okay with you, Shooter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Great. Whatever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just don't let it get wet again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've been quite busy on the telephone since I last saw you. There's a lot of interest all over the country in this game with Lancey and The Kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Betting interest?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jack Doyle in New York is giving twelve to five on Lancey. Same odds in Reno. I've taken fifty thousand of it so far.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fifty thousand!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll probably go for more but I didn't want to rock the odds.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I knew you liked The Kid's style but why you going in so deep?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two reasons. First, I want to see that smug old bastard gutted worse than he gutted me. Second, as long as that's going to happen, I don't see why I shouldn't make some money out of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But how can you be so sure? The Kid could do it, we both know that, but -- BILL "Could" isn't good enough for a man who hates to lose money as much as I do. He's going to need help -- from the best man with a pack of cards between Omaha and New Orleans.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not a chance, Bill. You ought to know I never ever use what I got with the cards for nothing but tricks and dressing up a game.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, I know it. That's why you're the man they choose to give them a square deal. That's what makes it so perfect. Nobody'll be looking for it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's out. Out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The great thing is they'll be so close, The Kid won't need much. Three or four key hands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Understand this, Bill. I'd like for The Kid to win, and I sure as hell don't want to see you lose all that money -- BILL If I did, I'd have to collect that twelve grand you owe me. Not myself. My collection agents. You knew poor Wildwood Jones, didn't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: but I'm paying it off! It's comin' in ain't it? Six grand already. (then as Bill just looks at him) Bill, you got to listen to me --!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I don't. It's quite the other way around. You have some delusion you're a free agent, but you're not. I own you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For God's sake --!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shut up. I'll cross the twelve off the books and give you ten thousand dollars in cash. And you can tell The Kid if he needs more of a stake, I'll put it up. (looks o.s. and smiles) Marvelous. Here's Rosanna with what you need.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: to include Rosanna carrying a tray with glasses and a pitcher full of Bloody Marys.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: for that dry feeling on the roof of your mouth. (TIME LAPSE)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It is raining dismally.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT - THE KID He is lying on one half of the bed, with the covers thrown back, his hands clasped behind his head, wearing pajama bottoms. He turns his head and stares at the white expanse of unoccupied bed. (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LOUIS STREET - DAY The weather is clear as The Kid wanders idly along a residential street of well-kept nineteenth century buildings. (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is drinking a bottle of beer slowly. CAMERA PANS to another bar stool where a customer is having his shoes shined by a NEGRO BOY who slaps his rag against the shoes with a fine sense of rhythm. Finished, he collects his dime and nickel tip, and moves to The Kid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Boy takes out a tobacco can with the lid torn off and the top flattened down and shakes it, producing a sound like the rustle of dry leaves. Then he produces a similar can that makes a rattling noise when he shakes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Boy looks at the BARTENDER, who has moved closer to see what's going on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Boy stands perfectly still for a few seconds, then begins to shake the can with corn in it. After a bit he brings in the shale stone can with the other hand to chord and accent the rustle of the first can. At the same time he begins to sing a simple song in a pure, delicate voice. It is catfish music created on the spot and sounds strangely like the idle tunes Christian likes to hum.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He rings up a NO SALE and flips a dime to The Boy, who is astonished and then worried by this munificence. Suddenly he grabs his tobacco cans and his shoe-shine kit, and runs out into the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Shine them up for you sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fetch you a newspaper maybe?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How about a singy-song then? I play good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Play what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dry corn in this one. Blue shale stone from the river in this one. You ready?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I'm ready.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to bartender) You ready?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hell, I'm ready for anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (when the song is over) Thank you very much. That was nice. Where did you learn to do that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I picked it up from Herman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who is Herman?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My friend I pick it up from.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is he a good friend?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know 'bout that suh. He just a frien' who teach me some things.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I don't want a shine, but here's fifteen cents.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And here's another dime for you, fella.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nice little colored kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mostly to himself)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: a masseur, is at work loosening up The Kid's neck and shoulders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Monday night, uh, Kid?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Monday night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I sprung for some of the action. A yard and a half of that five-to-two.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks, Jansen. (in pain) Hey!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We got to get you loosened up. I never felt you this tight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He is in the middle of a call.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone) Just tell The Shooter I'll be there on the dot Monday night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (over the phone) And until then?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He doesn't have to know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (into phone) I'm not asking for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hangs up the phone, rather than continue the discussion. CAMERA FOLLOWS him as he comes out of the booth, picks up a small duffel bag, and walks to the door that leads to the busses. He goes out into the night and gets into a bus. (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A bus drives along a main road in the Ozarks, heading toward CAMERA. As it comes close, the name of its destination: "FAYETTEVILLE" can be read.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bus stops momentarily at a small cluster of buildings around an intersection. The Kid is the only passenger to get off here. As the bus continues on its way, he goes to an attendant in a gas station on one corner, and asks a question. Referred to a general store and post office on another corner, he crosses and goes into it. The STOREKEEPER comes back outside with him to point out the route to where he wants to go. It is along a dirt road that winds uphill behind the store. The Kid starts up the road. (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid reaches the summit of the hill directly behind the crossroads, and looks down into the valley between this hill and the next one. He starts down an even narrower road leading to a little farm on a hillock in the valley. It consists of a modest cabin, a single barn, a fenced cow pasture, and a few cultivated fields. (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Christian comes around a curve in a path on one side of the house, carrying two five-gallon milk cans slung in a yoke over her shoulder. A little dog YAPS and runs from the front door of the house to the front gate. She looks in that direction and CAMERA MOVES to include The Kid as he unlatches the gate and walks toward her. After a moment's hesitation, she moves to meet him, gliding on her bare feet to keep the water in the cans from slopping out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns toward the side of the house and walks to the kitchen door. The Kid follows.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can I help you with those?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Taking if off is harder than taking it on in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How's The Shooter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You haven't played yet?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Monday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CRAIGIE MRS. CRAIGIE, Christian's mother, opens the door for them, giving The Kid a sharp, appraising glance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Christian crosses to the drain sink near the pump and turns her back. Mrs. Craigie lifts the cans off the yoke on to the drain board. She and Christian each take a can and pour the water from it to prime the pump.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid looks at the stove with a couple of large steaming pots on it, and the table alongside with a half-dozen hampers of green beans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As soon as they are finished with the pump, Mrs. Craigie and Christian turn to the table, where they begin to snip stems and cut beans before putting them into the pots on the stove.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid looks quickly at her and then at Mrs. Craigie, who keeps her gaze fixed on the beans.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is Eric, Mama. He's come to see me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CRAIGIE How do, Eric.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We lost suction on the pump right in the middle of canning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CRAIGIE There's coffee. And sour ham and bread in the warmer, if you're hungry Eric.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CRAIGIE You know anything about canning, you know we can't stop now. If we'd been looking for company, we never would have started.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Spring beans, you have to cook them fast. But you find yourself some breakfast.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm all right. Bus stopped for doughnuts and coffee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can stay with us tonight and still make it back to St. Lou on the Sunday schedule by about midnight. I told Mama and Papa about The Man. And all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where is Mr. Craigie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CRAIGIE To the barn. Why don't you go down and introduce yourself? Christian and me'll be at this another hour or two.
dialogue.name: dialogue
