dialogue.raw_text: I think I will. I think I'd like that. (to Christian) Okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure. And I'll see you a little later on. (then, as he starts out) Papa don't know everything. About you and me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He is pitching manure from all over the cow-lot into a pile banked against the side of the barn, working a long-handled shovel with practised ease. He looks o.s. and sees The Kid approaching but continues his work as The Kid enters the SHOT. Nor does he stop shoveling while they are talking, except at moments of particular significance to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid looks at him a long moment then -- KID You got any objections if I do, or if I don't? Craigie takes a couple of steps toward The Kid, his boots sucking in the muddy ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid takes his time before deciding how to answer this one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Craigie has finished piling the manure. He puts away his shovel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Craigie walks away. (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you do, Mr. Craigie. I'm Eric Stoner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Christian's Eric.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You seen her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's helping her mother can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You minding to marry Christian?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Son, that's what I call a sharp answer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was what I call a sharp question.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We don't know much about you, Christian's mother and me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm what's known as a three-river man. Which just means I go around playing stud poker wherever I can find the kind of action I'm looking for.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You met Christian when she was working to Hot Springs?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. I was playing in this game in the hotel and she was a waitress in the coffee shop. We went out. I told her I thought she could get a better job in St. Louis.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now how did you happen to tell her that? Maybe you run some kind of employment service on the side?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I said it because I wanted her in St. Louis. Anyway, she made it there and she called me and we been seeing each other ever since.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Living together?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, living together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How come she come home now? She going to have a baby?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not that I know of.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You two have a fight?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She must have had a reason.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Think so? Well, you've known her longer than me. (then) Look, Mr. Craigie, let me and Christian find out a few things then maybe I won't have to answer your questions.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I never run across anybody like you. I guess I don't understand gamblers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's all right. I don't understand farmers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You say things that sound smart alecky. But I'm not sure if they really are smart alecky.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well I can't take into account what somebody's going to feel every time I say something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you a believer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In some things.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean in God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's a tough one. I don't disbelieve in Him, but I couldn't say I believed in Him either. I guess I just never paid Him much mind. Didn't seem important.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God not important?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't mean what He does isn't important -- if He exists. I mean it's not important to me whether He exists or not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Christian was raised in a Christian home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that so? I didn't know --- (then) I'm not aware of the difference. (pause) I'm not asking permission to marry Christian, you know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I was, the only person I'd be asking it from is her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a moment) Who is this fella Christian says you're going to play that's so important?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's the king of the stud poker players.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you're going to play him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you any good?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm this good. The Man has got to play me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What happens if he don't?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then I'm The Man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That important to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I been trying to figure that out ever since I set it up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You playing because of money?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a moment) Not really.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Christian said you never was much worried about money -- I been worried about money most of my life -- up until I figured out it wasn't so important.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, it's necessary, but it isn't so important.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well how come you want to play this King fella?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ambition -- maybe security, like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is it aspiration to be the King or just uncertainty about the future?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I ain't looking for security if that's what you mean.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not trying to lock something up tight and nail it down?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That would figure into it. But that isn't all of it. -- It's important to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now son which is more important to you, this king business or Christian?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you got the guts to ask that question, Mr. Craigie, I guess I got the guts to answer it. Christian, if you came right down to it, is not as important as doing what I have to do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well son, I had to know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Know what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There never was a man worth a damn, to my mind, who let his woman stand in the way of the thing he had to do. (then) I got to go now -- see what I can do for a sick heifer. Why don't you take Christian, when her Mama lets go of her, and tell her I said you should go to the old spring. It's a good place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks. I'll tell her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SPRING - DAY It is a small shack against a rocky bluff. CAMERA PANS Christian and The Kid as they come down the path and enter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It stays warm all winter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: to reveal Christian and The Kid, who are in the pool without clothes, treading water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She starts to swim, CAMERA MOVING with her upper back as she reaches the side of the pool and pulls herself on to the bank, lying on her stomach. The Kid joins her, first drawing himself up on his stomach alongside her, then turning on his back to look through the slats at the sun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She raises herself up so that she is directly above him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Papa's mama used to bring her wash up here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We liable to draw an audience?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry. It's on our land -- Nobody uses it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You must have said something to Papa gave him the picture on us in St. Lou. Else he never would have spoke to you about this place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I told him on account of he already knew. Never any sense feeding a man a lie he's not going to believe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Even if he did know, I'm glad you told him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in mock protest) Hey, you're all wet!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So are you, foolish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The two men are sitting just outside the kitchen, where Mrs. Craigie and Christian are pasting labels on the mason jars they filled earlier. The paste and some of the jars are just inside an open window on a shelf behind the men's heads. The light comes from a kerosene lamp inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid stands up and selects six playing cards from a deck in his pocket. During the next few lines he uses the paste on the shelf to stick together three pairs of them so as to form three double-thick cards. One of these has two faces, another two backs, and the third a back and a face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He displays his three cards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid lifts a straw hat off a peg on the porch wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Craigie does as instructed. The ensuing dialogue assumes the card he picks is red on top; if it's white the words "red" and "white" will be reversed in the dialogue.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let me get this straight in my head. Cards is all a matter of luck, who gets dealt the best ones.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So when one of you professional gamblers sits down with a bunch of your -- what do you call them -- customers, clients?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The technical term is "suckers." Or "marks."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Their chance of winning is just as good as yours, except if you got a way to control it, who gets what cards. Right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not right. That's cheating and it's not any part of what we're talking about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then how do you win?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll show you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You see one of these cards is white on both sides, one is red on both sides, and the other is white on one side, red on the other.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This. I put the three cards in a hat and shake them up, and then I ask you to draw one card out blind. Put it face down on the table so neither of us can see the bottom side.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, red on top. That eliminates the all-white card, right. So the card you've picked is one of two -- the all-red or the red-and-white. One out of two is an even chance, an even-money proposition. Right -- you follow me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So if I said I'll bet you a dollar to seventy-five cents the other side of that card is red, you'd take the bet wouldn't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Seems like. Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And that answer makes you a sucker. Because the odds are two to one, the other side of that card is red, and I ought to be offering you a dollar to fifty cents instead of seventy- five.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But if there are just the two possibilities.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There are three possibilities. (indicating card on table) That can be the red side of the red- and-white card, or it can be either side of the all-red card. In two cases out of three the other side is red. And I'd win the bet from you two out of every three times we made it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dubiously) You would?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure. It's obvious when I explain it, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Reckon so. Except if there's only two things that the bottom side can be, red or white -- KID Take my word for it -- the odds are two to one. And knowing that is the difference between your gambling man and your sucker. Not who gets the better cards but who knows what the proper odds are. In a poker game there can be a million different situations, each with a different set of odds to figure. The man who ends up winners is the man who knows when to bet and how much...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The sucker is still took advantage of, isn't he? The gambler knows something he don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure -- like if you grow better corn or raise a cow that gives more milk than the other guy's. Or two business men are in competition, or two lawyers are up against each other in a courtroom. Whatever your line is, the one who wins out is the one who knows his job better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Seems like there should be something else to it -- KID There is -- Making the man you're playing against think he's got the best hand -- and making him pay to find out. (TIME LAPSE)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He is lying on a cot in the darkness, next to the big wood- burning stove. Christian enters the SHOT and slips under the covers with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is genuinely surprised at this and at first a bit dismayed. But her more considered reaction is one of pleasure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She kisses him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then they both react as Craigie can be heard getting up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gives him a quick kiss and stands up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I can't stay long. Papa'll be getting up to milk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm the one can't stay. I got to head for that bus.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why did you come, Kid?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, hell, I don't know. I had kind of a rough time after you left.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rough how?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tuesday there was a ball game, but then the Cardinals went on the road. I never known time to drag so; I was all torn apart -- CHRISTIAN Because of the poker game coming up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's how I read it, but I was reading it wrong. It wasn't Lancey or the game that was chewing at my insides -- CHRISTIAN What else is there could give you such a bad time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I finally figured it. I located where the trouble was. It was you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When you talk about doing something besides poker if I get to be The Man, you don't mean pass up the chance to make some dough from it for a while?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I sure don't. I told Papa, wherever money comes from, it feels the same when you spend it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You were going to do some thinking down here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I done some.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll be back after the game Christian -- You wait here for me and I'll let you know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right Eric -- Good luck Monday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got that made now. You said it right. My time's come.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The sun hasn't risen yet as The Kid boards the bus for St. Louis outside the general store.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid's bus crossing the endless plain in the afternoon sun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LOUIS BUS TERMINAL - NIGHT The clock above the loading platform says it is a little after two in the morning as the bus pulls up, and The Kid, groggy from the long ride, gets out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He enters wearily, goes straight into the bedroom and collapses on the bed. After a moment he summons the energy to loosen his shoelaces and kick his shoes off. But that completes his preparations for sleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Shooter is awake because he can't sleep, and Melba is awake because she is trying to persuade him to do what she considers prudent. He sighs deeply as she solicitously pours him a cup of coffee.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Twenty-five years I been building a reputation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Handle this thing right and your reputation will be better than ever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lancey is also awake, confronting a row of medicine bottles. He finishes laying out an assortment of four different pills and capsules, pours himself a glass of hot milk from a carafe, and proceeds to take the pills one at a time, with a sip of milk after each. (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid, looking completely refreshed, is readying himself for the game. He has chosen casual, comfortable clothes, and now he collects three items to take with him: a large bottle of mouthwash, a green sun-vizor, and finally, his stake. When he withdraws the money from the dresser drawer, we can see the pile has increased in size. The Kid finds an envelope to put it in, and he is ready to go. He starts out but in the middle of the kitchen he stops to look at his watch. It is too early. He crosses to the stove, pours himself a cup of coffee, and sits down to drink it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lancey has decided on a change of costume from his last game, and this time he goes for the old-fashioned velvet smoking jacket and silk foulard. Over this he puts on a light overcoat. Then he assembles medicines, toilet articles and money, putting them all into a small satchel. Finally, he puts on his hat and goes to the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We follow Lancey's progress as far as the elevator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Melba and Shooter have finished dressing, and he waits by the door while she does the inevitable last-minute things to her makeup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: EXT. CLOCK TOWER - NIGHT The hands are at 7:25.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I made up my mind to this. I ain't going to give him any help till he needs it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm glad you're taking a stand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, what if he starts off lucky and stays ahead of the game the whole way. It could happen, you know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll make it happen, Baby. I've got faith in you --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Kid is looking at the clock tower.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Once more around the square.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The taxi drives away from CAMERA following The Kid's instruction. CAMERA PANS to the front of the Dorset Hotel, which they have just passed. It is fifty years old or more, no longer elegant but still respectable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is standing at ease among old friends, sipping a creme de menthe frappe.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's a friendly town, St. Louis. I've always said that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: to take in the people around him, one after another. The Shooter is there, and Pig and Sokal and Hoban, and Melba and Hoban's woman and a couple of other women whose main attributes are physical, and Bill Schlaegel. Out of town representatives include LADY FINGERS, who is about fifty, down on her luck but still cheerful and remarkably energetic; and YELLER, a light-skinned Negro who has achieved stature in what is mainly a white man's world, through diplomacy and a quick wit. The room is the large living-room of a once splendid suite; there are enough chairs and couches around the walls to accommodate a good many spectators, while the middle of the room has been cleared for a round table with seven chairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lancey notices that most of the people around him have turned to look at the doorway. He glances in the same direction in a casual sort of way.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We ain't seen much of you though, last seven, eight years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Climate, Shooter. In my declining years, I spend more and more time in Florida and the Gulf Coast.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lot of folks been figuring another reason you was keeping clear of the three rivers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What reason is that, Lady Fingers?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cincinnati Kid. (laughs) That the way it is, Lancey? You been scared of The Kid?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Should I be scared of him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Damn right you should! I'm telling you, that boy going to make your stomach ulcer bleed before the night is out. He's close to murder. I seen him give a fella the shakes so bad on a fourth card, it took a pint of corn liquor to settle him down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks for the warning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He saunters toward Lancey. Almost everyone greets him, and he responds to as many as he can. Melba intercepts him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid would like these cryptic words explained, but Lady Fingers descends on him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid sees Lancey approaching, and turns to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly they both laugh over a private memory and shake hands, obviously old friends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns toward the center of the room. The Shooter follows him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mow the man down, sugar pie, make it quick and bloody. Been too many lean years for all of us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I intend to take Shooter right along with Lancey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not talking about the old Shooter. He's been factory rebuilt. A new spirit dwelleth in him, and his gaze is on distant hills.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you showed up after all. You're a braver boy than I thought, so much the worse for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think I'll be sorry I come?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bound to. That Lancey ain't human, he's one of them barracuda fish. He's liable to bleed to death, right on a flush hand before he give up to you. I seen him gut a fella so bad, the fella quit and got up and spit red in the john and went square.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Kid. Pleasure to know you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lancey. I been looking forward a long time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, sure. You seem to know about everybody. Yeller from New Orleans?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you say, Yeller? Still feeling salty with me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forgiven long since. (to Lancey) We had a little jurisdictional dispute.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hustled a couple of boys, right in his territory.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So I tried to tell him our rules down there. Colored marks are for colored hustlers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I tried to tell him how I got no prejudice. When I'm on the edge of my stake, I hustle anybody at all, regardless of race, creed or color. Anybody at all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Including my girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hell, I figured I was doin' you a favor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Lancey) Did you know Old Cottonhead died?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I hadn't heard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Heart give out in a high-low game.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning to The Kid) How you feel, Kid?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Great. You?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The best. You think maybe we ought to see if we can stir up some action?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whatever you say, Lancey. You're the -- (correcting himself) You're our guest in this town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I'm kind of in the mood to play a little cards.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think we ought to be able to get a game together in this crowd.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But first you take a look at things -- make sure everything's the way you want it. I already been around.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks. I'll do that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - KID AND SHOOTER The old, solidly built wooden table has been covered with a white linen cloth on top of a blanket. The cloth is tied down under the rim so that the surface of the table is flat, tight and cushioned by the blanket. The Kid presses his fingers into it to test these factors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lancey comes into the SHOT behind them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hoban comes into the SHOT with a dispatch case, which he sets on the table. He unlocks it with a key and turns it upside down. Thirty sealed decks of cards spill on the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a quick exchange of glances all around as the other three realize what the imaginary suspicion is behind Hoban's defensive reaction.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's an old table. Everything's pretty old in this hotel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's solid, that's what counts. And you got the top fixed perfect.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Light all right for you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two hundred watt bulb.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine, excellent. Okay with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, sure. Shooter's set us up just great.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure has.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, gents. Tried to do the best I could. (looks from one to the other) Cards?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good a time as any.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calling) Hoban! Okay! (to Kid and Lancey) You both know Joe Hoban. He's a draw poker man, but clean and straight as they come.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They come from the St. Louis Bridge Club, but they're poker size cards. They been bonded by the club steward and I seen him take them out of the safe. Shooter, Lady Fingers and me pick them up and come straight here with them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hoban's selling them to us at five dollars a pack, with the usual guarantee. If it's proved any deck is spooked, he pays off the losers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: St. Louis Bridge Club, eh? Steward still that old yard bird Okra?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (disturbed) That's him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (not noticing; to Kid) Old stud man, Okra.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Quite a character. Quite a character.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (anxiously) Nobody heard from me what the cards were for, Kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Kid) Been ten years since I seen or spoke to Old Okra.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Kay, fine. Don't worry about it, Lancey. Who's sitting down with us, Shooter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Four of us. Me, Pig, Yeller and Doc Sokal. If that's all right with you both?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Kay, fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, sure. (to Kid) Shall we have a look at the decks?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: with the pile of decks and the empty dispatch case on the table in front of them. They start checking the decks one by one, each putting the ones he has covered in a pile for the other's consideration. They examine the seals and the cellophane visually, and they also sniff both ends for the odor of a hot iron. By the time they are through with this process; The Kid has found three decks he isn't satisfied with, and Lancy two. The Kid passes his three rejects to Lancey, who tosses them back into the dispatch case without looking at them. Then Lancey tries to submit his two to The Kid, but The Kid waves them away, and Lancey throws them, too, into the case.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, Kid, what's your game?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: to include the other four players, who have come up to the table, still not taking chairs until Lancey and The Kid have chosen theirs. Though Lancey's question is purely ritualistic, they look to The Kid for his reply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Consulting the others is a formality, but all four of them -- Yeller, Shooter, Pig and Sokal -- nod or grunt or otherwise indicate assent.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't mind stud poker if that's okay with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got no objections to stud. (to the others) Gentlemen?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: across the room, he is indicating to The Shooter that he'd like a word with him before play begins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He detaches himself from the group and sidles inconspicuously over to Bill.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Tell The Kid I have a suite on the fifth floor. He can drop up during the breaks. Bedroom all for him any time he wants a nap.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's thoughtful of you, Bill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm a thoughtful man. I hope you are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Kid gestures to Lancey to choose his seat. Lancey acknowledges the courtesy, glances at the window and picks himself a chair facing away from it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid, following protocol, moves to a seat directly across from Lancey's. The Shooter takes his place at the table halfway between The Kid and Lancey, and pulls the twenty- five eligible packs of cards to him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Privilege of age. Can't take the glare of the morning sun in my eyes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want to have the usual brandy and coffee on hand, Kid? Anything special for you, Lancey?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why, yes, Shooter. Creme de menthe frappe. Green.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (glances around) You got that, Hoban? (to the table) Gentlemen, if there are no objections, I'm the dealer. These rooms have been contracted for, and there will be an ante of ten dollars per chair, per day. During the breaks for me, Old Lady Fingers has agreed to deal, but she don't care to be a player -- LADY FINGERS' VOICE Do too care!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: S to reveal Lady Fingers as she steps from among the spectators to a place behind Lancey.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Can't afford to play, that's the real truth. Had a bad year and I'm way over my edge.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lady Fingers will get three dollars an hour from the ante, plus her room and food, and a five-minute break every hour. Gents?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine, Shooter man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Kay with us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you don't see me when you need me, call room three-oh-eight. (taps Lancey's shoulder) You know who else ain't with us no more? Miriam, widow used to run the kitchen game to South Chi. Lost two month's Relief at blackjack, coal dealer cut her credit, and she froze in her bed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - FEATURING THE KID The Kid has taken his roll from his pocket and is counting it out rapidly. The other players watch, interested to see how much he is putting out. After counting out one stack of thirty hundreds, he distributes the rest in stacks of twenties, tens and fives, folding each bill over once as protection against picking up more than one at a time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid has completed his count.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Gentlemen, this is a game of five- card stud poker. There is no limit. A dead man has one half hour to raise his roll outside and get back in the game.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He takes the money from his satchel.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Five grand? Nice, tidy sum. I'll put out the same.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: S to Yeller.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I swear I don't know what I'm doing sitting down with you titans, but maybe it's worth putting up five thousand for the educational value.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: S to Pig as he brings out a roll and drops it casually in front of him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'll play with what I have in my pocket till I have to send out for more. Twenty-seven, twenty-eight hundred, I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: S past The Kid to Sokal, who is counting out bills from an impressive roll.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Five G's, I'm with it. Don't mean I'm goin' blow it all, though.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: S to The Shooter, who is counting out a smaller stake than anyone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He puts his money out without counting it, takes a deck of cards, rips the cellophane off it, takes the jokers and tosses them offhandedly to one side, not seeming to take aim.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Last and certainly least --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Heads turn as the cards sail through the air in unison, landing inside The Shooter's familiar hat, which is resting crown down on the mantelpiece. The spectators gape at the display of dexterity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He begins to shuffle and all eyes are upon him, not from suspicion but from pure admiration. He is in peak form, shuffling six times, once for each player and then slapping the cards down before Lancey, who is to the right of him, with an empty chair in between.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He waives his privilege of cutting with a barely perceptible nod.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Shooter acknowledges the compliment with the same sort of gesture. Then he begins to deal in his magnificently precise way, pitching each card so that it comes to a stop six inches in front of the player's money and in clear view of everyone at the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With Sokal in b.g. It is notable that as The Shooter completes dealing hole cards and switches to the first up card, there is no visible difference in the motion of his hands. He calls the cards as he deals them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Seven, nine, trey, nine, ace, and The Shooter guns up a ten. Ace bets.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ten dollars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dealer folds.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Call the sawbuck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He looks at his hole card: an ace.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Call.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Call.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Shooter deals again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Each other player folds in turn. The Shooter pulls in the cards, and The Kid pulls in the seventy dollars. The Shooter shuffles and deals again.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: King to the seven, pair of nines, deuce to the trey, queen-nine, ace- eight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nines bet twenty bucks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Queen, ten, king, four, ace again, and a king for The Shooter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ace bets ten dollars
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: King over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: They are perched on the back of a love seat at the far end of the room, with their feet on the arms. This gives them a view of the table through a pair of opera glasses they share, but they are far enough from it to be able to discuss the hands freely.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Shooter won't stay on a king or an ace if there's another one showing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's he have to have in the hole?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ten or better. With no other ten showing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The second round has been dealt. Sokal has a queen-eight, The Kid a pair of tens, Pig a king- seven, Lancey an ace- five. Yeller, like The Shooter, has folded on the first card. The Kid makes the same bet of twenty dollars, and the other three remaining players drop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Unhesitatingly, The Shooter pulls in the cards, separates them into four or five piles, and tears each pile in two. He glances around, and Hoban comes up behind him. The Shooter hands him the torn-up cards and unseals another pack, going through the same routine of throwing the jokers into his hat. (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: New deck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It is around midnight, and there is a more settled look to the game; some of the players have removed their coats, and there is a good deal of smoke in the air. The Kid has a cup of coffee by him, presumably with brandy in it; Lancey has his frappe; Pig is drinking whiskey; the Shooter and Yeller have bottles of bear. It is the end of a hand. With about six hundred dollars in the pot, Pig, who has been called, turns over his hole card triumphantly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Aces over eights. (waits for a challenge, but the others turn their cards) Thank you, gents. (as he pulls in money, to Yeller) Be a laugh if the two champs ended up cleaned.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He barely notices Pig's remark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He barely notices Lancey's reaction to Pig's remark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: among the spectators, who also have a more settled look about them. There is a bar, attended by a uniformed HOTEL BELLMAN, and most of the people are drinking. We see in passing a couple go through the door to the bedroom and close it behind them. CAMERA HOLDS on the love seat as Bill rejoin Hoban on their perch.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Any action?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shrugs) What do you expect first five or six hours?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Still feeling each other out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pig's ahead about a grand, Shooter maybe three hundred. (TIME LAPSE)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sokal gets a nine of clubs, The Kid a six, Pig a queen, Yeller a king, Lancey a jack, and The Shooter a four.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: King bets.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: to show the players. There is less oral accompaniment to the betting now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lancey calls, Shooter drops, Sokal calls, The Kid drops.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: King says twenty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In for twenty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dealing) To the nine a ten, to the queen a seven, to the king a jack, and to the jack a jack.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pair of jacks will venture a hundred dollars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (who has the nine and ten of clubs showing) I'm in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after studying the board) Up two hundred dollars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (folding) Leave it to the rich folk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lancey could be laying for him with three jacks.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Pig don't think so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Call the two hundred.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lancey puts in his money and so does Sokal.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sticking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Shooter deals another round: an eight of clubs to Sokal, a second seven to Pig, a ten to Lancey.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Possible straight flush, pair of sevens. Pair of jacks are still high.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Check to the sevens.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Likewise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (trying to be casual) Bet the size of the pot. Nine hundred and eighty dollars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In for nine eighty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll play.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: What's with Lancey? I thought he'd raise with three jacks or drop with two pair.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He probably thinks Pig's faking the queens. Anyhow, Doc's liable take them both with a straight or a flush.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: There is a good deal of suspense hanging on each card as The Shooter deals. Sokal gets a five of diamonds, and his disappointment is too great to conceal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: CLOSE SHOT - THE KID He watches Lancey, puzzled; this isn't what he had expected.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid relaxes; this is more the way he figured it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Busted, no flush, no straight. Pair of sevens with a queen gets a nine. To the pair of jacks, a trey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (counting his money, trying to be calm) Pair of sevens will bet whatever I got here. Twenty-four hundred bucks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll call your twenty-four hundred --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: and raise you whatever I have left.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lancey is completely calm. Pig is shattered, his whole world suddenly blown apart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All eyes are on Pig, which doesn't make it any easier for him. He just sits there, his hands shaking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is another long moment before Pig flips over his up cards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at Lancey with malevolence. Lancey turns over his up cards and tosses them in front of The Shooter. Pig suddenly lunges toward the cards, wanting a look at Lancey's hole card, but Lancey is too quick for him and pushes the cards into the pack The Shooter is assembling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pig is suffering, weighing the advantages and disadvantages of making the dread admission. Finally he nods. The Shooter takes a ten dollar bill from his own stake, and the other four remaining players each add a ten. The Shooter pushes the money toward Pig.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The other players look at The Shooter to see if he is going to accept this statement at face value. He nods, that he does, and each man contributes another ten. The Shooter passes the second fifty to Pig.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Comes to fourteen hundred fifty dollars, Pig. Don't imagine you'll have any problem promoting that much in half an hour -- plus whatever you care to raise me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fourteen fifty to the queens. You want to take your half hour, Pig?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I'm out. Out of the game.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Pig) You Tap City?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got a woman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought you and Hilda were quits.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See you around, Pig.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (ad lib) So long, Pig -- See you -- 'Night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (getting up) So long.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: him to the door. The spectators make room for him, no one saying anything. At the door, Pig turns back for his valedictory gesture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good luck -- Kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He has been rearranging his money, but Pig's words make his head jerk up and toward the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: to reveal the other players, who react in dismay to the breach of form.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With that, the tension is gone. But just to make sure, The Shooter pushes his chair back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He shouldn't have said that. Not after taking Tap City from the table.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His woman's been giving him a rough time. Wants him to quit and go square.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At his age? Crazy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He wants to wish anybody luck, doesn't bother me. Personally, I don't figure The Kid needs it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks, Lancey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know it's early, men, but what about taking a little break?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Melba fills a beer glass from a bottle and serves it to The Shooter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Shooter's gaze wanders o.s. CAMERA MOVES to FEATURE the objects of his attention, who are Lady Fingers, Lancey and The Kid. The two men would like to talk to each other, but Lady Finger's is monopolizing Lancey, and he doesn't want to offend her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Shooter comes to Lancey's rescue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He whisks her away. Lancey and The Kid, finally facing each other alone, don't quite know how to begin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lancey is a bit taken aback by The Kid's confident assertion, but he manages a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They look at each other and then exit.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Melba) It always distresses me, a man reaching his middle years and still having no assurance of next week's income.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know what you mean. I like a man to have plenty of assurance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Spider Man died kind of slow. First he give them a kidney, then his gall bladder, and then they taking his whole damn stomach. You remember Spider Man, run the dice table down at Turk's Club to Memphis.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who? Oh, Spider Man, sure, sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He died kind of slow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Need your help, Lady Fingers... to make arrangements for food and shelter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good crowd.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. Nice-looking broads.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's a fact.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That was a pretty thing to watch what you done to Pig with those jacks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks, Kid. From you, that's nice to hear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When he bet out first, he was ready to think you had them back to back. Even when he bet the size of the pot, he figured there was still a chance you were laying for him. But when you called him, I could see it in his eyes he thought you had jacks and tens, and I knew you had him hooked.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You knew, did you? Before I raised?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, sure, I seen what you were pulling all along.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You been to Miami, Kid?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Beautiful town, lot of loose money around. You ought to come down some time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, sure. Lot of room down there. Another spot you ought to work someday is Reno, Nevada.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I heard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got to have nerves though. So much going on. Action everywhere you turn. You lose the feel of the cards when you're in so much action day in, day out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd like to make it out there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's different levels of action there -- you'd find yours, any kind you could ask for.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I generally stick to stud.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, sure, for eating money. But you know how it is, I like to lay off once in a while and try craps. Nothing serious -- I don't even think of it as work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I do that. I'll take a night off and shoot a little casino. Or even blackjack.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your age, you don't need a regular vacation every year. But me, I have to forget the grind for a couple of weeks. I go to this place near Delray Beach, and the whole time I don't play anything but bridge.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's interesting. I could go for bridge if there was a way to do it without partners.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not keeping you from your woman, am I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a slight hesitation) No. We're -- she's gone away for a while. We're not sure we're looking for the same thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry to hear that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was hoping Christian would run with me and wouldn't try to make a big deal out of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But she tried?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, and now I don't know. I don't figure a man can change his way because the way I see it a man's lucky he's got something going for him that he can hold on to. A man can't change his way for a woman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nooo, a man can't do that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I been wondering if it isn't maybe a better idea not to look for a fixed thing. Just tie in to something nice when you're away from the action, and enjoy it, and let it wear itself out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a long moment) That's very interesting you should say that. You're pretty young to have figured things out already.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well she didn't understand how it was with me and --- LANCEY (warmly) Between us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There ain't but a few people, I guess who would understand -- LANCEY (as The Kid doesn't finish) Kid, you're the best stud man I've seen in 35 years of action. You know that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And when it comes to broads, which is getting to be an academic problem -- I can look back now to the two or three I ever considered I might want to spend the rest of my life with, and you know what? I like it... looking back on them, that is -- (then) I always got a lot of companionship out of a good book.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's very educational, hearing what it's like for a man your age.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Glad to be of help. And it's good we had this little talk so I know we can be friends regardless what happens.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That sounds good to me. I didn't think you was coming in at me like a grudge match.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No room for any kind of emotion in a fair game of stud. I learned that a long time ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Ready for some action, gentlemen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: INCLUDING THE POKER TABLE Lady Fingers is sitting in Shooter's place, rippling and shuffling the cards. Yeller, Sokal, and The Shooter are all either sitting at the table or standing near it. Lancey, followed by The Kid, returns to the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's a whole New Deal. Good hands all around. Prosperity for everybody.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're still good, Fingers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Getting crippled up, Lancey. Not many of the old gang left. You heard Whistling Sam was gone?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I didn't hear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was the one got called to the morgue to identify him. I don't suppose you seen anybody been run over by a twelve- ton bulldozer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, can't say that I have.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't go out of your way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Morning sunlight is streaming in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid, facing the sun, wears his eyeshade. The Shooter has resumed the deal and now hands out last cards to Sokal, The Kid and himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Bet the pot. Four hundred and twenty dollars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fold.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's yours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks, gents. Makes me exactly even. This kind of a game, that's a smart place to quit. (takes his money off the table) Just do the dealing, if that's all right with everybody.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It is later in the morning. Three players are left in the hand on the last card: Yeller with nothing higher than a jack, Lancey with a king-queen showing and Sokal with an ace- king.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeller pulls in the money in front of him. There is now about $19,500 left on the table, $11,500 in front of Lancey, $8,000 in front of The Kid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ace-king is the high man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shoot the works. (counts it out) Nine hundred and thirty bucks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (putting out the money) What have you got?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (unhappily) Doesn't matter. If you can call me, you beat me. Ace-king high.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning an ace) Ace-king-queen high.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to The Kid) I had them both with a pair of fives.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Winds it up for me, men. And I can't say it's been a pleasure. (despairingly) That one I was sure I could steal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lancey has a built-in burglar alarm. I'm also withdrawing from the field of battle, gentlemen. Settle for the seventeen hundred I've already dropped.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to The Kid) Well, just the two of us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, just the two of us. Deal them, Shooter Man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: There is around $1,500 in the pot. Shooter deals an unhelpful card to Lancey's pair of aces, and a nine to The Kid's king- queen-ten.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid turns up a jack and pulls in the money. (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Cost you a grand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Compulsory call, Kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The last bet has been made and there is about $3000 in the pot. Lancey exposes his hole card.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes in the money. (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Two pair, jacks up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Kings up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: There is $2500 in the pot. Lancey shows a pair of kings, The Kid an ace and three odd cards. The Shooter deals a nine to Lancey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is watching The Shooter intently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - KID'S P.O.V. The dealing motion looks perfectly legitimate as The Shooter gives The Kid an ace. Lancey's hand reaches into the SHOT to turn over his up cards.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Studded again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He takes the money in slowly, his eyes on The Shooter. Now the distribution of money has been reversed. The Kid has something under $12,000, Lancey something under $8,000.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He avoids meeting The Kid's gaze. (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - FROM BEHIND THE KID On the fourth card Lancey shows a pair of sevens, The Kid a pair of eights and a ten.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid lifts his hole card and we see it is a ten.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns to watch The Shooter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Two thousand dollars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Call two thousand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - KID'S P.O.V. Again there is no indication of improper dealing as The Shooter gives Lancey an odd card and The Kid a ten, completing his full house.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Two thousand more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Take it. I can't beat three sevens. (then as The Shooter's eyes flicker with surprise) I'd like a break to get some food and sleep -- I'm winners so it isn't up to me to say it but I'm saying it anyway. He exits. After a moment The Shooter follows. Lancey watches them go then rises, apparently still fresh and strong. Lady Fingers joins him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lancey looks at her a moment, then smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He moves through the crowd, then exits.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (pleasantly) My dear, that young man is a stud poker-playing son-of-a-bitch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gettin' to you, Lancey?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) Not yet he isn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: & SHOOTER They are alone in the room. Shooter is uncomfortable and would like to be elsewhere but The Kid is standing in front of the closed door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid grabs him and slams him against the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shooter looks at him, then moves towards the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Shooter goes out. The Kid crosses to the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LANCEY'S ROOM In the privacy of his room he shows how close he is to exhaustion. Wearily, he sits on the bed and begins to remove his shoes. Then, catching his reflection in the mirror, straightens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEDROOM, BILL'S SUITE - CLOSE SHOT - MELBA She is in the final stages of undressing. CAMERA MOVES with her as she steps to The Kid's bedside and gets into bed with him. Having accomplished this without waking him, she speaks into his ear in imitation of a hotel phone operator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He awakens in considerable confusion. Melba is amused by his difficulty in adjusting to his circumstances.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LANCEY'S ROOM He is shaving. Apparently much stronger but his hand is shaking. He looks at it. It steadies. After a moment he smiles a little. CUT TO INT. BATHROOM, BILL'S SUITE CAMERA is on the shower door as the SOUND of running water ceases. The Kid can be seen indistinctly through the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Melba, who is dressed again and applying her lipstick, comes into the SHOT, takes a towel from a rack and hands it to him after he opens the shower door. He gives himself a quick once-over with it, the secures it around his waist, steps out of the shower stall, and begins the process of shaving. Melba meanwhile finishes restoring her makeup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid stops shaving and looks at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a KNOCK on the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Now, just what the hell are you trying to pull?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (trying to bluff it) Nothing -- what are you talking about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You, Shooter Man -- you been feeding me cards for an hour.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angry and ashamed) The hell I was. (he waits a brief moment then eases away from The Kid) Christ, Kid, even if I was you couldn't spot it -- I'm too good a mechanic for anybody to spot it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grabbing him and slamming him against the wall again) But I was looking for it, Shooter -- four times you give me the cards I need.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a little shrill) You seen it before often enough. One player draws four good ones.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never in a game when I been told ahead the dealer has a stake in my coming out on top.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slumping) My woman told you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She told me enough to make me start thinking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (almost pleading) Why should you bitch if I give you a little help?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why, you dumb bastard? -- You have to ask me why. (ready to hit him) I could break you apart for what you've done.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (backing off) Kid, you got to understand. It wasn't my idea -- THE KID Well who the hell's was it then -- Schlaegel? -- SHOOTER He's got the squeeze on me Kid and he's meaner than hell. He'll cut me up if I don't come through. (then) You think I wanted to deal a phony game? You think it don't mean something to me? I never done a crooked thing before in my life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My ass bleeds for you -- Now you get straight on this. No fix. You come along straight or I blow it wide open.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's liable to kill me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He ain't goin' to do nothin' to you except pay off because I'm goin' to win.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is a hell of a chance to take.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got no choice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He ain't goin' to like it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (almost yelling at him) He ain't goin' to know. (then quietly) Shooter, I'm goin' to win this one -- win it my way -- and you ride with me or you're out, finished.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I ride with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You better not forget it -- now beat it. I need some sleep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell Mr. Schlaegel I accept his offer to use the room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone) I want to be called at 4 p.m. on the nose. For sure -- Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not yet he isn't. But he damn well might.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good afternoon, sir. It's exactly four o'clock.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's really only about twenty-five to four. You can stay right where you are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want you to think I'm getting too personal, but you mind telling me how the hell you come to be here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean you don't remember last night? We drank all that champagne and you said "Let's get married right away," and we chartered a plane to -- THE KID Can it -- (then) Where's Shooter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I locked the door. It's incredible the way you invariably worry about The Shooter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's incredible the way you invariably don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Worrying takes time and we don't have a lot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're supposed to sit down again at half past four.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Does it really matter so much to you now, that sense of obligation to The Shooter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (thinking about Shooter) I got no obligations to The Shooter. (then to Melba) Or to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Obligations are not what I have in mind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Reach me a towel?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You any idea how much The Shooter has involved in this game of yours?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If Schlaegel bet as much on me as I heard, I guess he'd pay a nice piece of change to be sure I won.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's worse than that. Schlaegel staked him for three years. He has his hooks so deep in Shooter Man, he'll take out his liver when he pulls them out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You asking me to go along with the fix?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm asking you to consider whether your ego is worth destroying another man's whole life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're still working for him. On my time you're still working for him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What kind of switch is this? You criticize me for trying to chippie on him, then I get a little loyal and you're at me for that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No -- I don't hold it against you. You wanting to make things right for him -- but this game I handle my way -- win, lose, or draw.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rolls and coffee for the hard-headed hero.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: S to take in the view of the bedroom as she crosses it to the door, talking as she goes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She has paused at the door to finish her sentence. Now she unlocks and opens it -- to Christian. Melba is so taken aback she can't do anything but stand there holding the door open. The Kid, in the bathroom in f.g., is similarly frozen in his tracks. After a moment Christian advances into the room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Believe me Kid there is too much at stake for us to rely on your doing it on your own.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .G. The scene as it looks to Christian is circumstantially incriminating. CAMERA MOVES with her gaze from The Kid to the one mussed bed, to Melba. The faces and the silence of the two people are even more incriminating than the circumstances.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She walks past CAMERA and a moment later comes the SOUND of the door closing behind her. The Kid, who has moved into the bedroom, crosses to his clothes on a chair, and picks up his undershorts and trousers. He returns to the bathroom, using the door for partial concealment as he removes his towel and puts on his shorts and trousers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid fastens his trousers and returns to the basin to give his face a last few strokes with the razor and wash off the soap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He comes back into the bedroom to finish dressing. As his movement brings him fairly close to Christian, he realizes he hasn't kissed her, and repairs the omission before putting his shirt on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To The Kid preoccupied by the game and the fix, feeling both affection and guilt. The idea that she can be any use to him against Lancey is one he can't grasp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He moves toward the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at him. After a moment he exits. She follows.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Kid. Hello, Melba. (a pause) You said wait home 'til you let me know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, that's what I said. We took a break in the game to catch some sleep. Shooter sent his woman up here to wake me up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I woke him up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It don't take much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I didn't find it any trouble. (awkwardly) Well, you children don't need me, that's for sure. See you downstairs. (to Christian) You, too, honey, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll be around if The Kid wants me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See you, Melba. Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Por nada, as they say. It was nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You been to the place?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I've got my bag downstairs. Maybe I'll take it over later on tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How's your Mama and Papa?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine. How's the game going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's come to be just me and Lancey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after the kiss) I was wondering.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got my mind on the cards.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know. And I don't want to rattle you. We got plenty to talk about, but it can all wait. Except I want to say this. I came back because I figured if it was going to work with us, it's silly me sitting home with Mama while you're playing your big game. I mean if I'm any use to you at all, this is when it's most important.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm glad you came, Christian. You got as much right here as anybody. (then) More right, I should have said.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Should you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hell, yes. The change I come out with when I win this one, you're going to be the one to spend it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eric -- THE KID (turning back) Look, I said I'm glad you came -- and that's all until I wrap this up -- I'm a poker player, remember?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It is evening. Lady Fingers deals a first up card to the two players. The Kid gets an eight, Lancey a jack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lady Fingers scoops up the cards, shuffles them into the rest of the deck, submits it to Lancey for his cut, and deals them another two cards apiece -- all in the space of seconds. The Kid gets a queen, Lancey a nine.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The eight'll try two bills.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning his card) No stay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two hundred.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning his card) No stay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: starts on Yeller, who is stretched out on the loveseat with his eyes closed and PANS UP to INCLUDE Hoban, who sits at the observation post with the binoculars. Yeller speaks without opening his eyes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Anything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Naaa, Kid paired kings. He wins a hundred.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: on PAST a window, showing it is night outside; past a group of other spectators; past Bill, Shooter and Melba who watch the game grimly; and finally to the table, where The Shooter is dealing again. The Kid is down to his undershirt, and even Lancey has made a few concessions to comfort. The players have just been dealt their third cards. Christian moves up to stand behind The Kid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks up at Christian.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hesitates. Then moves away. Lancey watches this. (TIME LAPSE)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Queen bets another C-note.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (folding) Take it away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go read a magazine, honey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It is later at night. The magazine lies open on Christian's lap; she is staring absently into space.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The announcement rouses Christian from her reverie.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) All right, gents. I'm declaring a break.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lady Fingers is in the dealer's chair. The two players look pretty weary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lady Fingers puts down the deck. Picks up a new one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lady Fingers looks at the two men for a long moment. Puts the cards down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns and stalks off. Lancey and The Kid look at each other for a moment, then both grin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he heads for the door, Lancey reacts to this. Then stands and looks around the room. Groups of people stand in the shadows watching silently, not hostile but certainly not friendly. He is The Man but he is getting beat and nobody is sorry. After a moment he turns and leaves from a side door. CAMERA PANS to HOLD on Christian as she stops The Kid by the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I break.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want a break.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I don't either.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Deal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (snapping) Same deck is good enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want a new deck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Alright, alright -- A new deck then, Jesus.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Deal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want to deal? Then deal them yourselves. I'm going to the john. I'm going to get something to eat, and I'm going to take a nap. You barracudas can snap all you want but at each other -- I'm taking a break and if you don't like it you can both go to hell.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess we been told.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Looks that way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rising) See you in about 3/4 of an hour, Lancey, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Make it an hour. Old bones need a little more time to loosen up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (meaning it) Listen, I think it is amazing you've been able to keep going this long.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (taking his hand) Eric -- SHOOTER (simultaneously) Your fan on the fifth floor wants you to have a bite with him. Alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Christian scans both their faces as they talk... concerned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He heads for the door. Christian looks after him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There's nothing to talk about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You better, Kid. You don't, you're only making worse trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you think so. (to Christian) Sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing, Nothing you have to worry about. I'll see you later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get something to eat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bill and The Kid are sitting at a room-service table. Bill nibbles at some cheese and crackers while The Kid tackles a large steak. Felix, the chauffeur, stands in attendance on them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He motions to Felix, indicating a wine bottle on the table. Felix steps over and refills The Kid's glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kid just looks at him -- then returns to his meal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He makes a peremptory gesture to Felix, who springs forward to offer the salad bowl to The Kid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Felix jumps into action again. He moves to The Kid's side, reaches into a breast pocket and takes out a switch blade, which he clocks open an inch or two from The Kid's neck. It is an extremely ugly-looking and menacing weapon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Felix hands the knife to The Kid, who tries it on his steak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He jams the knife in the table and snaps off the blade.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I thought it would be better if you and I sat down together to see if we couldn't work out our differences. Felix!
dialogue.name: dialogue
